docs.lead_paragraph: Claude Bouquet has been working on the railroad most of his life. Today his day began at the Montparnasse station in Paris at 7:39 A.M., when he hoisted himself into the engineer's cabin of a silver-and-blue, super-high-speed train so streamlined it seems to be streaking along even when standing still. In six more years Mr. Bouquet will be 50, and as an engineer, he can retire from the French National Railways soon after that at 74 percent of full pay, which now averages about $3,400 a month before taxes and payroll deductions.

headline.main: Speedy Ride on the French Railway Gives One View of the Labor Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman delivered her celebrated campaign promise to cut state income tax rates a year ahead of schedule, but she has yet to move as aggressively on her other campaign pledge to make government "smarter and smaller." State spending has risen $700 million since Mrs. Whitman took office two years ago and she has not fully paid the cost of the $1.2 billion reduction in income tax revenues with equivalent cuts in spending.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early last year, in a bellicose review of his first weeks as Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich proclaimed himself "a genuine revolutionary" who was going to change the world built by "the genuine reactionaries" in the Democratic Party. But on Wednesday, a tamer, conciliatory Newt Gingrich emerged, proffering modest budget and tax cuts designed to end the current budget impasse with the White House and start toward Republican goals one step at a time. Yesterday he persuaded his cohort to keep Government offices open for 45 more days while negotiations go forward. How can it be that in just one year the self-proclaimed revolutionary is suing for peace? It is not hard to see why Mr. Gingrich felt he had to trim back. President Clinton has surprised even his own supporters by standing firm against Republican threats to shut down the Government and limit its ability to issue debt. Polls show the public is fed up with Republican maneuvers and blames the Republicans more than the President for the budget deadlock. Even Wall Street was getting jittery as Moody's Investors Service announced that it was considering lowering its ratings for Treasury bonds because of fears the political gridlock would lead to default.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some legal rights grow more secure over time. But as Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, marked its 23d anniversary this week, that right is under siege across the country. Both houses of Congress have passed versions of a ban on late-term abortions involving a rare procedure performed after 20 weeks in a pregnancy. President Clinton has promised a veto. This is the first time since Roe that Congress has voted to ban any abortion method.

docs.lead_paragraph: A month after the end of the most disruptive strikes in a decade, French labor unions and the Government are squaring off for new confrontations, even though the most sensitive parts of the Government deficit-reduction plan that set off the unrest have been dropped. The Cabinet passed the most painful provision of the plan today, a new tax of one-half of 1 percent on all incomes over the next 13 years to pay off the $50 billion debt the health care system has accumulated. It goes into effect in February.

headline.main: French Battle Lines Form Again After a Month of Labor Peace
